body: I'm missing something. As far as I know, discovery packets == MSEARCH packets. What is the difference?
Ah, got it, you're talking about syncthing discovery, not UPnP discovery. That is very strange! Any chance of a firewall causing problems?
Well Python and any other utility is working fine, so I don't see why it would be a firewall thing.
FWIW, I ran the sample program you posted on my Ubuntu Linux machine, and the packets showed in Wireshark.

I think it's a Windows only problem.
If I only had strace...

It did work before so there must be some black magic involved.
I guess I need more people with Windows to test this to work out what the hell is happening, or to confirm it.
The described behavior (packets from test program don't show up in Wireshark) happens on my installation of 64-bit Windows 7 Pro SP1, with Go version 1.3.3 and Wireshark version 1.8.4
@AudriusButkevicius For the multicast case above, you may need `net.ListenMulticastUDP` and some other stuff for it to work...

@calmh if `net.ListenMulticastUDP` was necessary, wouldn't  the test fail under Linux as well? (I just re-ran the test program in my Ubuntu 14.04.1 installation with Go version 1.3.2 and Wireshark version 1.10.6, and the test still succeeded, with entries showing in Wireshark)
I think Windows is much more strict about what packets it allows out than Linux is. Perhaps it requires you to join a multicast group before sending packets to it.

issue.title: Use unique names for UPnP mappings (fixes #1100, fixes #1128)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body: I cannot really test this, because of #1113, hence would be nice if someone could take it out for a spin.

body:
@AudriusButkevicius the second test does not seem to work for me: I did not see any packets show up in Wireshark after running the second test in the same environment as the first.

Just to make sure I'm not missing a step, here's what I'm doing:
1. Copy the sample program into a text file, save it as "test2.go"
2. Run `go build test2.go`. No errors are reported
3. With Wireshark running, execute test2.exe

Expected result: broadcast UDP packets on port 1900 shown in Wireshark
Actual result: no relevant UDP packets shown in Wireshark

:(((
Sadly I cannot reporodice it on my machine anymore, making it hard to fix it.
Reopening for now, unless @cqcallaw confirms that this suddenly started working and started acquiring UPnP mappings on Windows.
